reviewText:
If you like JRPG, you can't go wrong with this FFX Remaster. In short, recommended, but with some warnings.

The game comes in two versions. FFX International, FFX-2 International - there are also two more extras: Eternal Calm for FFX and Last Mission for FFX-2. All is accessible from FFX's main launcher, of which it contains mini-settings to select language and graphic options also. Language is, sadly, tied directly to in-game dub. If you choose English, you can only hear English dub and English text, and so does for Japanese. There's a mod made by community so you can crossover the Japanese dub with English text (which seemingly majority of players like).

Graphic options, although presets are selectable from main launcher, the whole brand new settings are available in-game like Anisotropic, Vsync, AA, screen mode (borderless, windowed or full screen) and of course screen resolutions. No matter how monstrous your rig is, the game's locked to 30 FPS.  Whether it's pure laziness of their part or the game engine's limitation, I can't say for sure. But for playing experience, it's still fine although not the best one. At the very least you can adjust all to the max if your rig is powerful enough, or tone down the settings one by one so you can get stable FPS if your rig is weaker.

A few notable notes:
1. if your rig comes with dual-GPU like what's commonly found in laptop, the game preselects your WEAKER GPU. Make sure you force the GPU's control panel to select your better/dedicated card.
2. As of today 13/5/2016, the game often crashes when you select higher quality of the graphical settings. This should be fixable by patches from Square Enix, but who knows. To play safely, just set the options to lowest possible.
3. The game now offers fast-forward options, but movies are still not skippable. Very useful if you don't want to watch the scenes all over again if you had previously played its predecessors.
4. The game is DRM-free. Just execute FFX&X-2_LAUNCHER.exe if you want to play outside Steam. Keep in mind that you won't get achievement or Cloud Saving or Trading Card (as it's not registered properly with Steam) that way.

Audio comes with two options, the original version or arranged. Amazingly, you can change the setting on the fly through in-game option. At the end of the day, both versions are just fine for my ears, so it's just a matter of preferences. And no, it's not like Steam FF7's original MIDI releases, thankfully.

Gameplay and story, I don't have much to say as they are untouched and just carbon copy paste of the original releases.

As for the control options, the game offers fully customizable settings. If you dislike the default keyboard button assignments, there's a menu to rebind everything to your liking. I myself use my trusty F310 controller for this game and only had to tweak two buttons (swapping 'A' with 'B' function). And yeah, Square Enix's releases mostly only support Xinput, so for Dinput controllers you have no choice but to wrap it with x360ce for example.

With two games packaged into one, it makes sense that this game is more expensive than previous FF releases on Steam, so keep that in mind when you weigh based on pricing alone.

Overall, good game and recommended, they just need to fix the crash issues urgently and hopefully they listen - unlock 30 FPS limiter and give us skippable movies.

Okay, but seriously... here is my review.


Listen to my storyâ€¦ thisâ€¦ may be our last chance.

What can I say? To many, this game is an absolute classic, and to me one of my favourite games of all time. Never before have I been so moved by a video gameâ€™s story.

Final Fantasy X was made to make the huge leap to PS2, and also to pay homage to the classic Final Fantasyâ€™s combat system. It is an undeniable masterpiece, showing off that Square Enix were more than ready to make the next step in RPG gaming. In 2015, more than 13 years after its initial release, we were blessed with a HD Remaster to take us all back to how we felt all those many years ago. But now, in 2016, we are now blessed with the nostalgia bomb; our beloved Final Fantasy X on glorious PC. When this game popped up on my steam homepage I had to restrain myself from going bat â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ crazy.

Enough about my story with this game, letâ€™s get on to the easy-to-digest pros and cons:

Port Analysis: Itâ€™s a very good port (especially for Square Enix standards), probably even better than the PS3â€™s port, no graphics bugs or glitches so to speak of so far. My main gripe is that there is a 30FPS lock, but with a game like this itâ€™s tolerable. There are also a few sound bugs with footsteps and lag on attacks but these are minor. Emulator-esque game boosters come with this port which can speed up the game (except for cut scenes, annoyinglyâ€¦), increase or completely remove random encounters, supercharge your characters to ridiculous levels, and remove the HUD. There are also â€˜cheatsâ€™ which can give you 99 of all items or maximum AP. EDIT: I have discovered advanced graphics settings. They are accessed in game in the Esc menu. Many resolution options, borderless windowed and some basic low, medium, high graphic settings are available.

Pros (Brace yourself, there are many):

+ One of the best soundtracks in a video game youâ€™ll ever hear.

+ One of the most emotional roller coasters of a story in gaming. You will laugh, you will cry, you will fume, you will smile, this game is perfect for the sensitive soul.

+ An assortment of likable characters, no stale personalities here (â€˜cept for maybe Yuna, but you gotta have one straight man).

+ Very flexible levelling system with the sphere grid.

+ Beautiful CGI-cutscenes, even by todayâ€™s standards.

+ Combat System is classic turn based in X; solid, easy to pick up, and engaging. Some people may like the faster paced, ATB based system and those that do can play X-2 which uses that system instead.

+ Very good English dub. No Japanese voice option (modding can probably solve this), but if youâ€™re like me you mostly remember the English dub.

+ Upgraded visuals improve the gameâ€™s look and feel without detracting from its charm.

+ No need to grind too much. I played through the game fighting every encounter without fleeing and I was about high enough level to beat bosses.

+ Choice between original and remastered soundtracks.

+ Blitzball is exciting and luck based fun!

+ Addition of autosaves.

+ Controller intergration in great for the 360 Controller. Buttons are mapped fine with onscreen instructions. Vibration support as well.

+ Plenty of side quests and other hidden treasures to discover.

+ Extras previously only available in Japanese versions.

+ Over 40 hours of gameplay, and thatâ€™s just the main storyline!


Procons

~ Port is iffy. Works fine, plenty of graphics of options, but the dreaded 30FPS lock. Also there are sound glitches with footsteps and occasional lag.

~ CGI Cutscenes are unchanged. They still look good, I was just hoping SE would remake these cut scenes with their updated graphics engine. Then again, itâ€™s great for the nostalgia seekers like me.

~ For people unfamiliar with this game the Sphere grid may be confusing

~ Final Fantasy X-2


Cons

- People new to this game may think it is still dated, which it kind of is, letâ€™s be honestâ€¦

- Game is slow to progress in the first 8 or so hours.

- No Japanese voice (mods will fix this Iâ€™m sure).

- Un-skippable cutscenes (canâ€™t even be sped up through using the in-game boosters).

- Blitzball can be very infuriating when the RNG hates you. Also if you want to 100% the game and get all ultimate weapons you HAVE to play Blitzball.

- Combat is slower than ATB systems but can be mitigated with the hyperspeed boosters.



- One of the most cringiest cutscenes in the history of gaming, you all know the one I mean.


Overall:  Solid port, game lives up to its legacy as a widely regarded gaming masterpiece. To those who have never played this game and considering it, do it. Ignore the slightly dated animations and graphics, this game is one youâ€™ll never forget.

10/10

reviewText:
This game inspired me to become a musician when I was a kid...

I first saw it when a buddy of mine called me over, he just got his PS2. I sat and watched him play it for hours. Fastforward to Christmas, my older brother and I unboxed our very own PS2 with Kingdom Hearts and Tekken 4 inside. My mom bought us extra controllers so we wouldn't fight. Mine was blue, my brothers was red. The day after my mom took us out to spend money our grandparents gave us and I knew exactly what I was getting.

When I got home, my brother and I made our dad watch the intro scene with us. From there, it was a race to beat sin.

The point I'm making is that FFX was so powerful to the community of young gamers who evolved from SNES and PS1 JRPG's (Lufia, Chrono Trigger/Cross, Alundra, Musashi, FF 7/8/9) in a way that impacted our memories. It brought my brother and I together, which at the time was rare. The soundtrack would play through the house daily. It meant more that just a dip into nostalgia to play through it again, it brought me to a time when I first started to feel inspired by the medium.

For those who missed the chance to experience it years ago, I hope that you play it. It's worth every cent.

Final Fantasy X is widely considered to be one of the best RPGs on the PS2. It's HD re-release certainly looks good, but does the gameplay of X and X-2 still hold up?
FFX is #1 in the gaming history :)

I thought this Remaster was a huge upgrade to the original PS2 version (which is the only version prior to this I had played) and was a welcome walk down memory lane into one of FF's more touching titles. FFX has always had this depressing effect on me but it an ok way, it is just the amazing music blending in with the lovable characters and the feeling that something bad is going to happen to one of your beloved heroes.... Its a powerful feeling. The music is without a doubt top notch and manages to capture the moments both happy and sad (especially sad) and really make players feel the drama. FFX was also the 1st FF to have character dialogue and is looked upon by most as a milestone in FF history. And it surprised me just how attached I could get on my 8th play through. It brought me back years so long ago, when I was playing FFX on my PS2 when life was easy and carefree!! FFX-2 is an awesome game in its own right but doesn't hold a light to FFX as X-2 comes off as a far less serious and playful version of FFX. There is literally SO much content in between FFX & FFX-2 and its all on steam now. It is such a great deal for this HD Remaster for $30.00 / 20â‚¬ or however much you end up paying, its well worth it. There is over 100 hours of content in between the 2 (actually if your like me well more than that) but I recommend this to anyone who likes Final Fantasy of course, but also to fans who have played the older version. The graphic enhancements are stunning and are easily noted.  Also, ANY fan of RPG who doesn't own this should get it now. Beautiful story, amazing music, heartfelt characters & a sad life of the people of Spira. Its well worth it!!

reviewText:
I first played Final Fantasy X, arguably the best Final Fantasy installment, when I was just seven years old. It took me almost five years to finish the game on the PS2 back then (because I was that bad, and I played off and on). And when I finally did, I cried. The story had completely tugged and caressed my poor heart, and the characters had become like real friends to me. FFX is definitely the game that inspired me to begin my long journey as a gamer, and more importantly a Final Fantasy fanboy.

The minute I saw FFX/X-2 HD Remaster on Steam, I bought it in a heartbeat. I just finished the main storyline of FFX again, which is probably my second full play-through ever, and my first in about six years. As an adult, and as someone who already knew the plot, I thought that I would be able to hold back my emotions this time around.

I was wrong.

I wept and wept and wept. Choking on tears, I barely managed to watch the last cutscene. Bittersweet feelings and powerful music coupled with nostalgia, this game has brought me more entertainment, enjoyment, and heartwarm than any movie or game that I've ever watched or played, without exaggeration.

Seriously, if you haven't played FFX yet, then I highly recommend you play it now. The graphics and whatnot of the HD Remaster are not too shabby. And if you have played it, then... Why not play it again? I promise, the second time brings back so many more teary smiles than the first.

I haven't played FFX-2 yet, but I have high hopes. But even if FFX-2 is as bad as fans claim it to be, the fact that it's a sequel to FFX earns an automatic positive in my books.

I wish you all a pleasant pilgrimage through Spira.

EDIT: Clarity

reviewText:
I have to say I was a bit worried about this port since Lighting Returns is a stuttery mess for me in cities despite having more than ample hardware. This game, however, is miles better.

First, just to get it out of the way, yes this is capped at 30 FPS. But no, it does not affect the game at all. I was worried about that as well but the 30 fps is so consistant that it never takes you out of the game. All the game logic must be tied to the framerate because they did EVERYTHING else right.

There are a ton of graphics options. Everything you would want is there and the game looks amazing for what it is.

The game comes with every single extra you could possibly want. All of the international content from both games including the audio drama (even if it sucks).

Let me just end by saying they even included controller rumble in this port. None of the XIII games supported it. So that should give you a good idea about how they treated this game.

As far as Final Fantasy X goes, it's an amazing game. It's even better than I remembered it from all those years ago. If you like RPGs at all really, you owe it to yourself to give this a go. You can even get it for 18 bucks if you look around a bit.

I give it a 9/10. It looses only a point for the 30fps cap because of how little it affects the game.

reviewText:
I can't make an honest review without nostalgia clouding my judgement, just very happy they decided to port this over (along with FFIX) to PC, Haven't played this in at least 12 years. This port has to be the most stable on PC, only 1 crash (in FFX-2 i might add) in 56 hours. You get decent amount of tweak-able graphics options and although it doesn't look current gen, the polish they added to the textures really make the game look as it did when it was first released, if you know what I mean.

It is locked to 30fps, but you wont really notice it for the most part, since it isn't a twitch shooter. I know that will bother most people, but you are really screwing yourself out of a classic jrpg if you let that be a deciding factor in your purchase for this collection.

FF-X2, I hated it at first, never had the chance to play it back in the days of the ps2 era, I was disappointed in the direction they decided to go in terms of the games atmosphere and tone, but if you can get past the cringe inducing awkwardness of certain sections of the game there is some gold to be found. Haven't completed it yet, but there is somewhat of a decent plot, and there are some serious story driven moments, but right after it just gets nullified by OTT campy humour.

The battle system was something I didn't take to at first either, the mix of real-time and turn based combat didn't gel with me and was quite confusing at first, especially how claustrophobic the camera seems to make me feel when there are your 3 party members and 4 enemies scattered around a tiny battle map. With characters/enemies or the angle of the camera skewing your LOS on the action. But it does add an element of tension in battles, and makes for way more exciting gameplay.

One thing that let's it done tremendously though is that the only way you can reduce damage from attacks (like when you are low hp) is if you pick the warrior class, and also if one or two of your characters goes down it can be impossible to revive them and keep them alive due to needing the bar to fill up before you can use and item, and then further waiting time to actually USE THE ITEM. Making a simple phoenix down and potion combo a pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥, due to an enemy constantly trying to kill the character you are constantly reviving.

Scenario : Yuna on low hp, she is a gunner, she cant â€œdefendâ€ to reduce damage, Paine's action bar has filled up and you decide to use a potion to heal yuna, during the 5 seconds it takes for Paine to rummage around to find the potion, Yuna gets hit and is KO'd, Paine finds the potion and now decides to heal herself. You then try to use a phoenix down, after 10 seconds, you successfully revive Yuna, fiend/boss attacks Yuna again, she gets KO'd, rinse repeat.

Don't listen or jump on the internet hate band wagon for ffx-2, some bad design decisions/tone etc do make the haters complaints justified, and it is not necessarily a great game or even a good one, but there are moments in it that make the game worthwhile to play through, and I can't wait to see how the story progresses.

All in all, a wonderful job from Square Enix (never thought I could say that about Enix xD), a fully functioning port that just gets the nostalgia flowing. Will be playing this now for years to come. Thank you!

Product received for free

I first played Final Fantasy X when I was about 11-12 years old. I loved it but could never get past one of the boss fights, meaning I never got to experience over half of the game. Instead I played lots of blitzball, lost tonnes of matches but still loved every second.

I saw that Square Enix where going to stream this remaster just before release and decided to tune in. Entered a giveaway and won!

The port is fantastic, I've crashed once I think in the 60 hours I've played, which was my fault for bringing my PC to a slow.

I have finally finished FFX and it lived up to every expectation I had since my first playing on PS2. It is hard to believe the game was released so long ago, it easily competes with modern AAA games and is a good price in my opinion.

The story is very engaging and character development is great. The English voices are really not as bad as people say, I admit the timing in parts is bad, but the voices grow on you and you'll learn to love them.

There is so much to do outside of the story too, lots of places to explore, new and old. Plenty of optional bosses and various activities such as Blitzball and the Monster Arena.

There are in built cheats/boosts to make the game a breeze if you'd rather focus on story and not the optional encounters. I personally have not used them as it takes away the fun for me as I love the battles.

I am excited to go into FFX-2 blind after all these years. But this is worth it just for FFX.

reviewText:
Despite my low hours, I've played and beaten this before on PS2 (actually, I think a lot of us have already, probably you too if you're reading this). Even so, if you're a newbie to this game, here's a bit of information for you.. You've got a great cast of characters, all voiced, along with an enthralling story and amazing summons. At the time this game came out, the CGIs were amazing. There was nothing like it. And  voiced games weren't that common at the time. Also, the way the character's facial expressions changed to show their emotions was  revolutionary. Actually, now when I think about it, FFX did a lot of things first, which changed the way how a lot of people looked at games. I dont think you'd have such great and believeable characters in later games such as The Last of Us and Heavy Rain if FFX never came out. It truly was the game which forced the gaming industry to evolve beyond the ps1 era.

Looking at port quality, I really have to say that unlike a lot of their previous ports, they did a very good job with this one. You get the upgraded graphics of the PS4 version, all the international version content, original and arranged soundtracks, eternal calm, last mission, and probably even more that I'm forgetting. Oh, did I mention boosters? You can turn off enemy encounters, turn on turbo, have all basic items, get max gil, etc. Great option for people who dont have much time playing games, or those who have already beaten this game multiple times. Or well...those who just want to cheese..

Now, to be fair, it does have a 30 FPS lock, but so did the original. I've seen people be very vocal about this lock but in all honestly, if you're used to how the original plays, this shouldn't bother you. If it's still an issue for you, there's a mod coming out in a few months I heard which changes the game's framerate to 60, so you'd have to be patient for that.

All in all, if you, like me, havent played this title in ages and itching for a new FF game to replay or just want to experience  it for the first time, this is a very good version of the game to get into.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy X was an amazing experience when I was young. Now, replaying it in HD glory is a huge nostalgia hit. The score (both revised, and original) is outstanding. The story is deep, rich, and an emotional journey for both the characters and the player. The gameplay may seem tedious to those that don't find RPGs appealing, but many will be love it. If not the animations and art style, simply fly through a battle and take in the music. Even now I have the menu in the background for the music alone. Added 'cheat' features give replayability, and something to mess with if you get bored. The graphics have (obviously) been redone to look good, but it doesn't lose the feel of the original.

Final Fantasy X alone is worth the full price. If you've played the original, you'll love going back. If not, you're in for an incredible journey. However, you also get Final Fantasy X-2...

While not as good as Final Fantasy X, FFX2 is still a very enjoyable game. The score is once again brilliant, the cutscenes breathtaking, and it gives closure to the story. The gameplay and RPG elements are different, but fun to play with and experiment. It's a nice balance of difficulty too.

Keep an eye out for cutscenes in both FFX & FFX2 then glue your finger to the screenshot button, trust me.

reviewText:
A good port of a good Final Fantasy game.
This review will only cover Final Fantasy X as I haven't tried X-2 yet.

Final Fantasy X broke the PS1 era mould a little bit by bringing FF back to its traditional turn based roots. I personally think the game is better for it, but objectively it may be a little bit slow for people who are used to the faster ATB system. It also allows you to switch characters freely during battle (with only three active characters at once). The switch system adds an exciting element to the battles, because it feels like you can freely exploilt enemy weaknesses on the fly, and you can use every character instead of only focusing on a few.

Another way it broke the mould was by removing the traditional level up system and using a level up grid called the Sphere Grid[i.imgur.com](expert grid)[i.imgur.com]. This has both pros and cons but is essentially a more visually stimulating standard level up system. Choice doesn't really play a big role here unless you use the expert grid, but generally you won't be using the expert grid due to issues you have later in the game. The benefits of the sphere grid system lie in the fact that you can see future abilities you will acquire and notice significant power increases after moving for a while on the grid.

The character balance is fine throughout the main storyline, but there's one character that tends to be weaker than the rest due to the fact that he has no specialisation and feels a few steps behind whoever he decides to tail on the grid. Post game balance is pretty bad with the fact that you'll only use 4/8 of the characters. This is less important as obviously post game content tends to be done with efficiency in mind so players probably won't mind.

In terms of the writing, the characters are pretty consistently good with a few common anime tropes thrown in. They're all charming though, even if some of the scenes can be a little bit cringey. The writing is good, and the overall plot is actually very interesting. It avoids falling into some of the shonen cliches and the game is definitely better for it. The world is grim and it definitely lets you feel the main themes of the game, which are death and hope.

The music is top notch with a great leitmotif that they use at the correct times to make you feel the beats of the story more accurately. The theme of the game was a song called Suteki Da Ne" which I personally don't care for as much as 'Eyes on Me' or 'Melodies of Life'. Not to say that it's bad
date: I just don't enjoy the singer too much so I find it hard to listen to it as much as the other main FF themes.\n\nOk

here's a quick pros/cons list to finish this review off.

Pros:

+ Interesting plot

reviewText:
I have to be honest here, I bought this game thinking it was going to be a nasty port like 90% of all the other FF games they have ported to PC but hell man.. NO WAY! is this game a bad port. I personally think it's the best port yet for any FF game to PC. That said, sure.. the game has it's minor issues that im NOT worried about really,

1. 30fps,
2. The built in cheats system BUT that can be used at your own choice.
3. Battle music not working after playing the game for too long BUT that can be sorted by just restarting the game.
4. Minor graphical issues, like the cloud background in Mt.Gagazette during the cut scenes, you can clearly see a line/tear of the panoramic background where it loops around, BUT who cares about that..? you see it for all of like 5 seconds.
5. SOME things are hard to do if your using a Keyboard.. like getting more than 4 casts on Lulu's Overdrive. BUT all other keyboard settings are so easy to use, but you could just use a game pad if you have one.. which I don't :(

My MAIN GRIPE with this port..

6. Is the fact that you cant download the games seperatly, you need to D/L it all at a massive 37gig(ish).. which took like 7/8 hours for it to complete. Whoever came up with the idea to have it like that should be fired, though it DOES look nice and tidy and it's as friendly as hell.. easy to use menu system.
7. Tidus is STILL a whiney bi@tch! wish they had changed/reworked HIS dialogue.

Other than the above said issues, this game is fantastic, AND an awsome price to boot with everything you get with it.

Final Fantasy X is one of my favorite RPGS of all time. I completed this game already before with full completion yet I find myself years later playing it all over again and enjoying every moment of it. reviewText:
One of the better SE Final Fantasy ports.

Overall the game exists as it does on the PS4 version of the remaster.  The biggest improvements are in the graphics settings, which allow you to change AA, resolution, etc etc.  There are more settings available than in any FF port yet.

Another notable inclusion is the ability to change from the vanilla audio to the remastered audio on the fly (I heavily prefer the original soundtrack).

There are a couple minor letdowns.  First, keyboard support still sucks.  Play this game with a controller.  Second, menus are 60fps and the game is locked to 30fps.  If these aren't dealbreakers for you, this is probably the best version of this game to enjoy.  I can't wait to put another 100 hours into Spira.

reviewText:
2 Final Fantasy games in one;
FFX - Boy gets pulled into a world of chaos, boy meets girl, family drama, what could go wrong?
FFX-2 - A mission based game, with Yuna continuing her journey to find someone familiar... could it be ...?

There are some additions to the original game;
Creature Creator - capture and train creatures (FFX-2), put them in your party and they'll auto-fight along side you!
Cheat options added in (F1/2/3/4) for on the spot encounter rate, character boosts, max gill etc (FFX/FFX-2).
AutoSaves - with an adorably cute and animated chocobo icon.
Random bits pulled in from international console versions;
Dark Aeons  (FFX)
Expert Sphere Grid (FFX)
Possibly other things I haven't noticed yet.

Square Enix seems to have improved a bit; the game seems stable, pretty, scales well on our 4K TV and actually plays properly, which is more to be said of previous ports. Texture stretching during animations (eye iris's stretching for example)... seems to be the only major grind I have with it and even then, it's rare.

For extra 'spice', also works with ReShade (DX11) to flavor out the graphics a little more.

They get one good review from me finally, at least for effort. I can actually play this and it works well with SteamLink.

reviewText:
Product received for free

In this classic walking simulator from Squaresoft with no overworld map or proper airship, you control a ragtag group of misfits whose goal it is later revealed is to kill Luke Skywalker's father. Underwater polo provides a distraction from the main story, but often you find yourself wishing the characters would hurry up and drown so you have something more interesting to do.

Cutscenes are not skippable and do a lot to pad the length of the game. You may find this frustrating as battles with Jabba the Hutt, who is eager to get into Leia's pants, will require you to watch the same 10 minute cutscene multiple times if unsuccessful.

reviewText:
The game runs very well and looks amazing for its age. Yes it is capped at 30FPS, but that's because when the game was made it was common practice to tie some of the game physics and logic to frame rate. So to raise the cap they'd have to rewrite some code, which as anyone who has ever done any coding knows has a huge cascade effect.

In other words, yes it's capped, no it's not a big deal, and no it isn't an easy fix for the developer.

Overall very pleased we got a release of this game at all, let alone the excellent performing version we seem to have, and am looking forward to the long hours I'm going to put into this game again.

After such a long time the game is finally out on steam, and it was worth the wait.

This game version is the ps4 remastered verison with the updated interface, new remastered music and just fixes and general improvments over the original.
The port is really a step up for Squeenix, no glitches, crahses or freezes or frame dips as of now, the graphical options are  many and make the game look smoother and better than ever.

*Making cutscenes skippable, it's kinda annoying if you've maybe died on a boss or just want to skip that you have to sit through a cutscenes,this is quite the problem because this game has more than 11 hours of cutscenes.The new autosave system does help abit, but i feel as if it could be improved.

This is a reveiw of X(10) not X-2(The sequel) so keep that in mind

Def worth a pickup if you maybe want to try a final fantasy game, or if you want to relive nostalgia, Square has done an pretty decent job.

reviewText:
Update: May 22 2016.

Short version: It's a good port with an amazing redone soundtrack. Seriously this game is worth getting just for the arranged music.

Longer version:

Gameplay is exactly the same as the PS2 and redone versions for the PS3, PSVita, and PS4. That means turn based combat, sphere grid upgrade, blitzball, and unskippable text cutscenes. If this is your first time with the game you'll get the gist of it from any gameplay video for any of the versions listed above.

Mechanic wise, like the other reviews say it's locked to 30 fps. Considering the type of game it is fine. I like the high fps but since it's a port of a game of two generations ago the fact that it even runs at a constant 30 is good enough in my book. I spoke earlier about the music. You're allowed to choose between the new soundtrack or the original. I'll recommend the new one again because it really is beautiful. I haven't tried my ps4 controller on the game, but it has correct button mapping for the Xbox one. I don't own a Steam Controller so I can't test it.

The textures are HD." You can tell from the screenshots that they are updated from the original but they don't hold to any of the latest game realeases. Square Enix has always been pretty famous for their cgi scenes so those still look incredible.

That's pretty much it. Game runs exactly as it does on other platforms so that means it's a good port. Good port means it's a recommended buy. So get it. Just be careful of the infamous laugh scene. Make sure  you're the only one in the room.

reviewText:
*Editing This to be more proper*

Aside from the amazing nostalgia trip that you get addicted to, this is a FANTASTIC PORT! It feels exactly like the original game and even gives you the ability to choose between classic and remastered music for the game!

Things I like:
- Graphics are great in 1080p, still looks solid!
- Remastered music captures the beauty of the original soundtrack, but enhances the quality!
- You can choose classic or remastered version!
- Fantastic Port! Runs games with no issues so far!
- Comes in with English and Japanese languages in-case you can't handle the dubbed voices
- Smoothest 30 fps I have ever seen, no stutters or nothing

Things that are Meh:
- 30 FPS. I am not an FPS snob, but I know it matters for some people

The remastered music is a fantastic adition and it does the soundtrack justice! The combat is same as before and its really fun, the visuals are better at 1080p. Framerate is locked at 30fps, but the 30fps is steady and smooth, no framedrops ever, even at high density areas or high particle effect battles. A toaster can run this game and it will still give you that amazing feel of going back and playing FF X and FF X-2! Will update the review if necesarry, but so far I can say that this is a worthy buy!

reviewText:
Final Fantasy X review: THIS. Just THIS. This game embodies one of those times when Final Fantasy as a game series shines at its brightest. Final Fantasy X was my first Final Fantasy, and I will never, ever forget the way it blew open my world as a young teenager. They say that your first Final Fantasy is the one that will always be the best - I am so, so deeply thankful that this was my first. (FF VII lovers, sorry, but you'll have to come second.) This fact alone is even more incredible if you think about it as a testament to the quality of the Final Fantasy series, when usually your first anything sucks horse poop. Yeah. Think about it.

Anyways, this remaster basically brushes up the original game just enough so that you get sucked into the world of Spira all over again (in HD!!). Yes, the character models are a little inconsistent, in that the main characters have all gotten South-Korean perfect facelifts more in line with the CG cutscenes, while NPCs at times look like they've been injected with too much Botox with blurry textures for makeup. The infamous HahahaHAHAHAHA scene is still there, in all its cringeworthy glory. Auron's just as cool as ever, Tidus is still whiny, Yuna's prettier than before... Everything is there as you would like to remember it... Yes, even the now kinda outdated stiff character animations.

The sphere grid upgrade system still holds up after more than a decade - it's incredible how much it makes sense in terms of accessibility and enjoyability, unlike some certain other games (*cough* FF XII *cough*). The game runs smoothly without a hitch on a Geforce card, and is perfectly compatible with an Xbox controller. Oh! And finally, even though the game is locked at 30 fps, I either didn't notice it because everything was so consistent, or I simply didn't have time to care because I was too busy enjoying the game and storyline - again.

For those of you who've played it before, you know what I'm talking about. For those of you who haven't played it before - You will cringe, you will get the feels, you will laugh, you will cheer on this unlikely group of characters as they take on the world around them. So...What are you waiting for? Everyone's waiting for you. Spira awaits, with all its dreams and splendor and broken glory.  BUY THE GAME. NOW.

The graphics do look very nice on high setting and I noticed no performance issues that are worth mentioning. There is the issue that it's capped at 30 FPS but for this game that's fine. Sure 60 would of been nice but really it's not really a complaint at all and it's very stable and runs fluidly.

FFX is a must play. If you never played this game due to never owning the consoles that it was released on or for whatever reason, you have to experience it and I feel the Steam version is the best version and I've played the PS4 version but the small extras do make it worth it.

The gameplay is very good and reminds me of a time when Final Fantasy wasn't heavily relient on auto battle, it does stand the test of time and with the remastered version you are able to chose between two different sphere grids and the expert grid does make it more interesting and make it nice to explore with your characters and customize them to your liking.

reviewText:
What can I say, this game was my childhood. An amazing adventure, and in my opinion the best of the Final Fantasy series. Some of the moments in this game just...stayed with me, for years. Final Fantasy X features Tidus, a blitzball player from a futuristic city called Zanarkand. His life changes forever when a mysterious force called Sin sends him 1000 years into the future.

The port itself works beautifully, bringing a PS2 game flawlessly to computer with smooth 60 FPS and and the remaster looks so much better on a good graphics card than it ever did on PS3/Vita. The arranged chorus is a great revamp on the classic music of this game,  but if it's your first time playing you should choose the original music.

It works with Steam Link and Steam Controller, but the controller doesn't work out of the box so you'll need to do some tinkering to get it to work. Also, the game itself defaults to Japanese, which is a bit annoying. You'll want to change the settings in the launcher before you start the game.

If you have any interest in RPGs or Final Fantasy, you NEED to play this game.

reviewText:
It plays just how I remembered it.

Now I didn't get the ps3 remaster because I knew that since the ps4 was going to release soon, there would be no point in getting it since it would just get ported to the ps4, which it obviously did. I didn't get the ps4 remaster due to some rumormill talk about the remastered edition coming to the pc. Low and behold, it has.

First off, for those of you who don't know, this game is a remaster of the international X and X-2 due to the fact that more content was released on those versions.
At the start of a new game with X you have the option to chose the Standard Sphere Grid, which all of us here in the America's grew up with. Then you have a second option to chose. Expert, which let's you pick where you want your characters to start out at in the sphere grid, rather than having everyone on their own set path.
For example, you could make Tidus the White Mage(healer), Yuna the Tank, Kimari the Black Mage, and so on. So if you ever felt that a character had a more fitting role as something else, or you just want to balance each character a little better, or you just want to say â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ it and just mess around by giving everyone random rolls, you can in the Expert Sphere Grid Version.
Another option has been added, besides the adjustable graphics, you can give yourself all of the consumable items and max gill. That's pretty usefull if you just want to try and speed run this game. It doesn't give you any of the Al Bhed primers or any other Key Items, so you don't need to worry about the game locking up on you at a certain point should you chose to use those options.

Pros:
Adjustable Graphic settings that can go as high as your set up can support

Amazing remaster

Beautiful Sound Track

Great Nostalgia Trip


Cons:

Locked at 30 fps

No Japanese Audio

Illuminati


8/10
wood nostalg again

reviewText:
Final Fantasy X review: THIS. Just THIS. This game embodies one of those times when Final Fantasy as a game series shines at its brightest. Final Fantasy X was my first Final Fantasy, and I will never, ever forget the way it blew open my world as a young teenager. They say that your first Final Fantasy is the one that will always be the best - I am so, so deeply thankful that this was my first. (FF VII lovers, sorry, but you'll have to come second.) This fact alone is even more incredible if you think about it as a testament to the quality of the Final Fantasy series, when usually your first anything sucks horse poop. Yeah. Think about it.

Anyways, this remaster basically brushes up the original game just enough so that you get sucked into the world of Spira all over again (in HD!!). Yes, the character models are a little inconsistent, in that the main characters have all gotten South-Korean perfect facelifts more in line with the CG cutscenes, while NPCs at times look like they've been injected with too much Botox with blurry textures for makeup. The infamous HahahaHAHAHAHA scene is still there, in all its cringeworthy glory. Auron's just as cool as ever, Tidus is still whiny, Yuna's prettier than before... Everything is there as you would like to remember it... Yes, even the now kinda outdated stiff character animations.

The sphere grid upgrade system still holds up after more than a decade - it's incredible how much it makes sense in terms of accessibility and enjoyability, unlike some certain other games (*cough* FF XII *cough*). The game runs smoothly without a hitch on a Geforce card, and is perfectly compatible with an Xbox controller. Oh! And finally, even though the game is locked at 30 fps, I either didn't notice it because everything was so consistent, or I simply didn't have time to care because I was too busy enjoying the game and storyline - again.

For those of you who've played it before, you know what I'm talking about. For those of you who haven't played it before - You will cringe, you will get the feels, you will laugh, you will cheer on this unlikely group of characters as they take on the world around them. So...What are you waiting for? Everyone's waiting for you. Spira awaits, with all its dreams and splendor and broken glory.  BUY THE GAME. NOW.

Final Fantasy X-2 review:... Ok, I wasn't really as a much of a fan, but it's still fun. It's not as emotionally heavy as FFX, but if you like seeing women MCs in skimpier clothing and flashing their dance moves... Well. Look, it's not quite a strip club. I promise.

reviewText:
Background: I owned the PS2 version of FFX, I own the PS3 HD version, and of course the PC version. I will predominantly speak about FFX, as that is the game I have the most time with. This game was one that I became very attached to while beginning my first year of college (I had played it a little before, but just on and off again before that). Because of this, please realize that I may be biased and looking through glasses of nostalgia!

The Game Itself: The game is wonderful with a great battle system, a great story, good graphics, great music, and true voice acting for the first time in a Final Fantasy game. The battle system is the standard random encounters found in most FF games but the battle system itself is good and gives quite a bit of flexibility for the player of how to battle. The sphere grid allows wonderful customization for your characters, especially with the expert grid" activated from the International Version. This was made widely accessible to NA audiences beginning with the PS3 remaster and the PC port follows suit.

The story is wonderful with a deep and twisting plot to save the land of Spira from a creature named "Sin." The characters are generally deep and their development is wonderful to watch. One can quickly become connected with the different types of personalities and the core of their circumstances.

reviewText: I am only reviewing the first game, since I have not yet played X-2. Being relatively new to the Final Fantasy series and having only played the modern FF 13 series, FFX hd was an amazing and a much more superior experience. For a game that originally came out in 2002, it offers a fantastic story with well written characters that you really care for and has some heartbreaking moments, especially the ending scenes which almost made me cry. In regards to the game mechanics, there is a turn based battle system and each character has their own sphere grid, which you can upgrade as you progress through the game defeating monsters and bosses. There is no excessive need for grinding like in other jrpgs, which is less frustrating.\n\nThere is plenty of content to do in this game, i have only finished the main story and havent done any optional areas and bosses. In addition, a mod makes you play the game with Japanese voices and English subtitles, which i thought was pretty cool and really added to the immersion. The soundtrack in this game is also phenomenal with some standout battle themes and there is also an option to switch between the original and remastered OST whenver you want. The only negative i can think of right now is the lack of a cutscene skip option, which was sometimes very annoying, having to go through  a lengthy cutscene whenever you die at certain bosses. If you are a JRPG fan, i wholeheartedly recommend this game at the normal price, since you get both FFX and X-2, even better when you get it on sale.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy X is a good game. Its graphics are pretty decent (even today they could be much worse), and its gameplay is fun, following a similar pattern of turn-based combat as its predecessors. Its story isn't my favourite FF story, but it is still pretty damn good. It also has plenty of difficult challenges, such as the optional bosses later on (good luck beating them without cheating - you're going to need a lot of time to do a lot of farming). It does have a few flaws, like the Tidus laughing scene, but overall, it's a pretty fun game with a pretty immersive story. It also has a fun time-killer in the form of Blitzball, a fictional sport within the world of Spira. With recruitable players around the game's world, it can be fun to play in Blitzball tounraments and leagues.

Final Fantasy X-2 however... I don't have fond memories of this one. The storyline is a bit â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ in all honesty. It's not the worst mind you, but a few important things that FFX establishes get u-turned in FFX-2, including what makes the ending of FFX so touching (that just makes me feel that Square didn't feel fully committed to the ending they chose for FFX). The gameplay is also an issue in my opinion (you might like it of course, it's a kind of love it or hate it thing). Instead of keeping with the tradition of meeting multiple characters throughout the game, you are restricted to the three characters you start with. Obviously, it can be hard for a JRPG to give only three characters all of the abilities of what would usually spread across seven or eight of them. The way that FFX-2 gets around this is through dress spheres, a mechanic that lets you change your outfit mid-battle to use different abilities. Whilst this is a take on the classic job changing system of III and V, unlike those games, it is poorly implemented here. It kind of takes you out of the game when half of it is spent playing dress-up. A lot of Final Fantasy fans would say that FFX-2 is one of, if not the worst Final Fantasy game in existence due to its story and gameplay, which is a shame as it is the sequal to a decent game.

Overall, this is worth it just for the first game, but while you're at it, you may as well give the second one a go. It's not everyone's cup of tea (I guess you could call it an acquired taste), but if you have it, you may as well see if you like it or not for yourself.

reviewText:
Regarding the port, it is great. The games are locked to 30 FPS, but this is because of the fact that the game is so old and many engine things are tied to FPS. There are built-in cheats like speed-up, encounter rate modification, invincible characters, and more that don't seem to break achievements. The games work great and are separated by a relatively non-intrusive launcher. For a pair of games that I never thought would get ported to PC, I'm really happy with the port. It really couldn't be very much better than it is.

Regarding the games, if you haven't played either of them before they might be a bit strange.

FFX is a much more serious game than FFX-2, but the story is a victim of an awkward translation and mediocre voice acting. Although the acting itself isn't necessarily bad, it is evident that none of the lines were recorded together and things feel really disjointed. As a result, the story can get a bit cloudy at times, but it still packs an emotional punch at the right moments.

The gameplay is a bit slow for modern standards, and there's a lot of waiting for animations or just walking long distances. The speed-up cheat can be a godsend through some parts that need grinding and when you're traversing a huge empty map. If you're patient though, FFX is a great game.

FFX-2 somehow takes the story from the first game and turns a bunch of the characters into pop stars. It is a really weird game and kind of continues the story of FFX, if you're really intrigued, but the gameplay is what will really keep you going through this one. The job system and combat systems are both really fun, and I'm kind of sad they haven't made a good appearance since then.

This is a great compilation if you want to replay these games. For people playing for the first time, be warned that they are not quite timeless, and instead have some really glaring age-related problems.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy X is a good game. Its graphics are pretty decent (even today they could be much worse), and its gameplay is fun, following a similar pattern of turn-based combat as its predecessors. Its story isn't my favourite FF story, but it is still pretty damn good. It also has plenty of difficult challenges, such as the optional bosses later on (good luck beating them without cheating - you're going to need a lot of time to do a lot of farming). It does have a few flaws, like the Tidus laughing scene, but overall, it's a pretty fun game with a pretty immersive story. It also has a fun time-killer in the form of Blitzball, a fictional sport within the world of Spira. With recruitable players around the game's world, it can be fun to play in Blitzball tounraments and leagues.

Final Fantasy X-2 however... I don't have fond memories of this one. The storyline is a bit â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ in all honesty. It's not the worst mind you, but a few important things that FFX establishes get u-turned in FFX-2, including what makes the ending of FFX so touching (that just makes me feel that Square didn't feel fully committed to the ending they chose for FFX). The gameplay is also an issue in my opinion (you might like it of course, it's a kind of love it or hate it thing). Instead of keeping with the tradition of meeting multiple characters throughout the game, you are restricted to the three characters you start with. Obviously, it can be hard for a JRPG to give only three characters all of the abilities of what would usually spread across seven or eight of them. The way that FFX-2 gets around this is through dress spheres, a mechanic that lets you change your outfit mid-battle to use different abilities. Whilst this is a take on the classic job changing system of III and V, unlike those games, it is poorly implemented here. It kind of takes you out of the game when half of it is spent playing dress-up. A lot of Final Fantasy fans would say that FFX-2 is one of, if not the worst Final Fantasy game in existence due to its story and gameplay, which is a shame as it is the sequal to a decent game.

Overall, this is worth it just for the first game, but while you're at it, you may as well give the second one a go. It's not everyone's cup of tea (I guess you could call it an acquired taste), but if you have it, you may as well see if you like it or not for yourself.

reviewText:
It plays just how I remembered it.

Now I didn't get the ps3 remaster because I knew that since the ps4 was going to release soon, there would be no point in getting it since it would just get ported to the ps4, which it obviously did. I didn't get the ps4 remaster due to some rumormill talk about the remastered edition coming to the pc. Low and behold, it has.

First off, for those of you who don't know, this game is a remaster of the international X and X-2 due to the fact that more content was released on those versions.
At the start of a new game with X you have the option to chose the Standard Sphere Grid, which all of us here in the America's grew up with. Then you have a second option to chose. Expert, which let's you pick where you want your characters to start out at in the sphere grid, rather than having everyone on their own set path.
For example, you could make Tidus the White Mage(healer), Yuna the Tank, Kimari the Black Mage, and so on. So if you ever felt that a character had a more fitting role as something else, or you just want to balance each character a little better, or you just want to say â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ it and just mess around by giving everyone random rolls, you can in the Expert Sphere Grid Version.
Another option has been added, besides the adjustable graphics, you can give yourself all of the consumable items and max gill. That's pretty usefull if you just want to try and speed run this game. It doesn't give you any of the Al Bhed primers or any other Key Items, so you don't need to worry about the game locking up on you at a certain point should you chose to use those options.

Pros:
Adjustable Graphic settings that can go as high as your set up can support

Amazing remaster

Beautiful Sound Track

Great Nostalgia Trip


Cons:

Locked at 30 fps

No Japanese Audio

Illuminati


8/10
wood nostalg again

Only 2.6 hours into my current game.  But with many hundreds played throughout PS2 and PS3, I'm in a place to confirm that this is still the greatest Final Fantasy game, and  still one of the best RPGs ever made, and still, one of the greatest games of all time.

Dat soundtrack... You know the one.

So lets review this based on my experience on how this port has played. I'm rocking an i5 2500, GTX 970, 8gb ram, and it's running like  a dream, and it's stunning in Full HD too.

The options are intriguing, and you can set up, sort of a God Mode. But I'm going to play it the old way. There is also the option to use a different soundtrack, but again, I didn't, because I wanted to experience the game as I remember it.

I've seen reviews stating this is constantly crashing and people are having a hard time with it. Not so for me, which leads me to think it's more of a them issue.

If you want the nostalgia, pick it up. Pick it up anyway, This is a timeless classic, and X-2 wasn't too bad either, a game that ended the story amazingly. just remember if you do, you have the Chocobo race to do again!

And currently, it's a steal at Â£15.99 for both.

A massive yes from me. If you'll excuse me though, I've got to get back to Spira.

reviewText:
I picked up the HD remastered versions of Final Fantasy X/X-2 on PS3 when they came out last month, and I replayed FFX for the first time in probably at least 10 years. I remember really enjoying when I first played it and I was worried my memory of the game would be greater than what the game actually was. But I enjoyed it quite a bit a second time around and it held up pretty well aside from the horrendous cutscenes. It's crazy to think about how Square just churned out hit after hit of amazing classic RPGs from this franchise in the 90s and early 00s and then to think about what garbage the FF series has given us since this game.

A quick sidenote for those who never played a game in this series or are otherwise unaware: The stories and battle mechanics of each game in the Final Fantasy series are completely unrelated. Each game in the series has a completely new cast of characters and settings, and there's nearly always a different battle system with different battle mechanics and rules. The series has some common elements and reoccurring motifs; for instance there's usually magic or summon monsters and for some reason there's almost always a character named Cid that appears somewhere in the game. But you don't have to have played FF9 before FF10 or anything like that.

FF10 (or FFX for you Romans) follows the story of a young man named Tidus who is a star blitzball player from the futuristic city of Zanarkand. Blitzball is some kind of crazy combination of football and soccer, but played underwater. It also serves as FFX's primary minigame. It's kind of broken and clunky, but the football fan in me enjoys it despite its faults. Anyway, in the game's prologue, the Zanarkand blitzball arena is suddenly attacked by a massive whale-looking monster known as Sin". Sin magically transports Tidus 1000 years into the future to another world called "Spira". While searching for a way to get back home to Zanarkand
date: Tidus learns about the world of Spira and befriends some of its residents. He learns that Spira has always been under constant torment by the same Sin monster he encountered in Zanarkand. Tidus soon befriends a young girl
hoursPlayed: who is training to become a summoner in hopes to obtain a summon monster powerful enough to destroy Sin. FFX's main storyline deals with Tidus
voteText: Yuna and her guardian's journey across Spira and their quest to defeat Sin.\n\nI found the story and pacing for FFX to be both very good. Now the thing that's an absolute trainwreck and nearly ruins the game are the voice acting and cutscenes. Final Fantasy X was the first game in the series to be voice acted

votesHelpful: that's pretty much how all of the cutscenes in this game are. Now the actual story that is behind these cutscenes is pretty good. But oh man

votesFunny: not how the game is showing it. If you can't do that
commentsCount: you'll probably find this game's story pretty laughable. No pun intended.\n\nFinal Fantasy X's battle system is pretty tight and well balanced. Information like damage
column17: and weaknesses are clearly communicated to the player during battle instead of having to guess which enemies are weak vs. which elements or try to figure out whether the status effect spell you just cast was successful based on what color a sprite is. If you equip your party with the proper "sensor weapons"
column18: you will even see strategies on how to defeat specific enemies
column20: and what their weaknesses are. It's the kind of useful information the FF series always used to hide in the background instead of telling you straight up for some reason. There's a good variety of enemies that all have strengths and weaknesses to different members of your party. For instance flying-type monsters need to be taken down by a ranged fighter
column21: while Tidus' sword is effective on smaller more nimble monsters. Still others may be weak to magic spells and require a Mage to defeat. It's a fun
column22: strategic turn-based battle system that will have you rotating your party members in and out in order to try to exploit enemies' weaknesses.\n\nFFX is notable for not having a world map to explore
column23: which is normally a series staple for Final Fantasy. I was afraid this would be too much like FFXIII
column24: a game which I hated for having linear corridor after linear corridor strung together as level design. But you never really get that feeling in FFX. The level design does a good job with divergent paths and interesting things to do and people to talk to in all of the areas to make you forget there's no world map linking everything together. The level design and pacing is pretty good in this game... except for the puzzle solving sections in stupid cloister of trails areas. People who have played this game before know what I'm talking about. Tedious
column25: time wasting puzzles with random arbitrary logic that you have to solve by trial and error. Terrible game design. Whoever put these in the game needs to be smacked upside the head.\n\nFinal Fantasy X also is notable for being the first game in the series that was not exclusively composed by the legendary Nobuo Uematsu. some tracks are more subtle and little less "in your face" than the originals and probably more appropriate in certain areas. But at least include the option for me to switch back to the old ones if I want!

reviewText:
A fantastic port that does almost everything right.

It's the same FFX you know and love, but with a fresh coat of paint.  Assuming you liked it on the PS2, you'll be able to fall in love all over again with the PC version.

Let me start with the cons, as they are few but still annoying.

- Still no ability to skip cut scenes.
- The minigames are still terrible.
- Inputting Auron's overdrive prompts on a non-PS2 controller has been clumbsy.
- It's the same game, so if you hated it back in the day, you'll still hate it now.
- Seriously, why can't we skip cutscenes?

Really, that's it.  Now for the overwhelming pros.

- Runs smoothly, without issue.  Immediately recognized my controller, had no crashes or freezes or even any bugs.
- Runs QUICKLY.  The PS3 Remastered version had load times, not long ones, but still noticeable, especially when entering several different rooms at once; you'd see the spinning Jecht symbol and have to wait five seconds.  This version has none of that.  Much faster.
- Remastered textures.  The games looks better than ever (though little if any different from the PS3/4 remastered versions).
- Additional content (compared to US PS2 version).  You can now fight the Dark Aeons and Penace, as well as use minor new abilities and equipment, not to mention the Expert Sphere Grid.
- PC Perks.  At the press of a button, you can have no random encounters or one every two steps; you can speed the gameplay up x2 or x4; you can even enter a 'cheat mode' where you have max stats.  This speeds things up so much.  Farming for the monster area?  Turn on turbo and more encounters and you'll be done in less than half the time.  Fantastic.
- The Creature Creator in FFX2 deserves a special shoutout.  Yes, FFX2 is an abomination, yada yada, I know ... but Creator Creature is fun!  You can access it after the introduction and just go to town.  It almost makes the rest of the game less disasterific.
- Can choose between original or the enhanced soundtrack, and the original or expert sphere grids.
- Still the same game, so if you loved it back in the day, you'll feel the same today.

This is the forth time I've bought a version of FFX, and this is the best version, hands-down.  How often can you say that about a port of a console game?

reviewText:
Ever since around 2007? I've had a dream of playing my favorite game on the PC. I've downloaded many emulators and the PAL release in order to play FFX to it's fullest and put a lot of time into playing the content that was cut from the NTSC release. One of my benchmarks for my PC builds was always if it could run FFX on PCSX2 at full speed and 1080 scaling. How surprised I was when FFX HD was announced initially for consoles & the Vita and I immediately pre-ordered it, something I haven't done since FFX-2 came out. I played the game for over 150 hours, and 100% beat the game and got every trophy on the vita release, and here we are 2 years later and I get to dodge 200 lightning strikes again on the PC and I won't hesitate to do so.

Final Fantasy X is where Square Enix peaked with the franchise IMO, and it hasn't had a title that captures the emotion of the series, formula, and gameplay all in one title since. If you have never played an Final Fantasy title I highly recommend you start with this one and work your way backwards if you enjoy the game.

It is an overall good port, depsite being locked at 30 fps and with some easy to insert mods you can play the game in japanese voices if the Tidus laugh scene annoys you that much.

reviewText:
FFX: I would say that it is the best RPG of it's age, and among the best of the series, if not the best. It has a beautifully tragic story, and the sphere grid is a lovely way to level. It was a game of firsts, and set the bar for how we would view big-budget RPGs. Released before DLC was a thing, it made you practice the art of the sidequest. If you are an FF or Square fan, this game is a must have.

FFX-2: Was not a fan of the combat style, nor of some of the things square chose to do with the story. It does bring some nice closure to the fates of the survivors from Yuna's Pilgrimage, and is coupled with some beautiful songs.  For the completionists, this game may fall short compared to the first, but is worth the playthrough, if only for the story, songs and seeing Yuna and Rikku in less restrictive clothing. Also, some of the mini-games are worth a look, if you have some patience and a good memory.

Note: My time played clock isn't accurate due to not playing steam games while online.

reviewText:
Overall if you have played Final Fantasy X and/or Final Fantasy X-2 before, then you know what to expect from the story and the gameplay. The remaster has added a completely re-done soundtrack to the game, and higher resolution textures and visuals. The original CGI cutscenes introduced in the PS2 version are completely unscathed, however.
The PC version of Final Fantasy X has some added features such as Turbo Speed, Auto HP regen/Overdrive Mode, the ability to toggle on/off encounters, and auto AI battle mode. I wouldn't recommend these options for someone playing through the first time through the game as it might ruin the experience. Final Fantasy X-2 has a different set of cheat options.

My only complaint is that there is no option to skip cutscenes. This is my fifth(?) time playing through Final Fantasy X and I have to watch the cutscenes over and over again.  I understand they want you playing this game for the experience. I get it. But still not having this option in the year 2016 is beyond my level of understanding. Especially considering most of the people who are going to buy this game have probably played it before. You can still choose to skip cutscenes in FFX-2, but why would you want to miss out on that 100%?

Overall this is a good game, but not a great one. Keep Netflix or Crunchyroll on hand while playing this game to make sure you don't bore yourself to tears.

Im doing this review from the perspective of a 33 year old man who originally played this game when it was released for the PS2. So basically i played the original and then went on to play this remaster many years later.

So lets start with whats called the TURD sandwich - We put out all the games GOOD and BAD points all in 1 go and then explain the details

BAD -
1) Remastered faces - Congrates square enix - aside from Lulu and expressionless kimahri all the characters new faces suck balls! Tidus face now looks cartoon like with chubby cheeks and slope eyes, Auron looks as if he is wearing lipstick in some parts, Wakka looks as if he has had a mild stroke.....i know its a remaster but WHY did square-enix have to mess the faces up and remove model nodes so less expressions would show. Everything else they did was great so why ruin the  face nodes and make it so less emotion comes through?

GOOD -
2) This is the LAST great game from SquareSOFT - not that r-tarded company square-Enix who havent produced a good game in over 10 years but squareSOFT! - ie the masters who gave us Chrono Cross/Trigger , tobal 1+2 , Xenogears, Parasite Eve , Front misson 3 and various others. FFx-2 was by Square-Enix and NOT squareSOFT. GOOD -

This is how i USED to think the story went when i was younger - sin appears and destroys zanarkand, Auron takes tidus to sin who is actually jecht, jecht teleports tidus to the future but in order for this to happen tidus has become a ghost the same as auron. They meet Yuna and go on the adventure and in the end defeat sin, stop Yevon who turn out to be bad guys, Tidus finds out he isnt alive anymore and passes on once sin is defeated.

Now THIS is how F-ing confusing it ACTUALLY is
Zanarkand ISNT real.........its DREAM zanarkand, tidus jecht and all the millons of people who live there are not real, Auron who died at the hands of Yunaleska died and then went to dream zanarkand to meet tidus, sin just APPEARS and destroys dream zanarkand without any explanation as to sins origins, Yunaleska whos meant to be all powerful just gets her A-hole handed to her in 1 fight, jecht isnt real but comes to spira.........and never mentions how his city worked? no trade with other countries or anything like that? Then Yevon turn out to be bad guys just ....because....and then everyone in Yevon turns out to be evil....because....and then the Al Bhed who have been seen as the bad guys for hundreads of years are suddenly not seen in this way half way through the game, Yuna through the entire game NOW just comes accross as if shes desperate for sausage - she flirts with tidus right away and makes it clear she want some. She hardly knows a thing about him yet flirts like mad with him in the first hour of the game. REAL zanarkand was destroyed 1000years ago, dream zanarkand wasnt because it was a dream.........so wtf is the start of the game about?

The rest of the story is more complicated but i wont even start with how stupid this story is when you combine it with x-2's which really makes absolute SOD-ALL sense considering sin was defeated and Yevon shouldnt be around anymore

5) BAD -
FORCED buy of FFx-2
Im saying forced because its clear square-enix just did this to make more sales and sell the games as a bundle rather than seperate and see X did amazingly well while x-2 sells badly. The price isnt bad........if your buying the game off ebay, steams price is a tad too high for a 10+ year old game

6) GOOD -
Original music - we have the proper music in this and a remix (which no one will use) so thankfully you wont have to mod the original music BACK into the game like what people had to do with FF8

7) GOOD -
The gameplay is a good now as it was then, its a great battle system ..............However you then play x-2 and see how crap its become........then slowly realise this was the start of all the other crap games square-enix would release like FF13 which was a 80hour tutorial. I say Play X and pretend X-2 doesnt happen

8) BAD -
x-2 in a nutshell 'I want to find tidus again - then spends 90% of game not looking for tidus' the story is bad, the battle system is bad, the world now seems dull with everyone split up and no sin, your rival is a pink woman with x2 idiot goons, bad comedy, CLONE tidus who isnt tidus......or is he? considering GHOST zanarkand wasnt real then do the ghosts just live the same lives over and over? coz clone tidus LOOKS like normal Tidus. The we have the idiot monster robot under yevons basement.................................sigh

9) BAD -
Emo Lesbain Femenist Paine
She is perhaps the WORST character added into a game in the entire history of the FF franchise. Not only was she clearly added in last minute (Which is plain as day considering almost zero characters have conversations with her aside from 1 guy with a walking stick........for 1 part.....and thats it....and then afew conversations with Yuna and Rikki were paines responce is either -yes,no, or a sentance which could have been slotted in anywere) but her character in general is just crap. She was made clearly for 1 target audience but just comes across as a fortgettable character who doesnt have 1 good thing about her. Some people have tried to defend her by claiming she is a female Squall from FF8..............im not sure what idiot pills these people are on but Squall wasnt an emo lesbian femenist with zero character growth and who sucked. X-2 im not sure if it was TRYING to be funny by just having 3 moody women going on a dull adventure were they face off against pink villian and fat camp man and thin camp man while looking for clone tidus.......but this game ISNT funny like CAMP funny like what the HyperDimensional Neptunia games are which ARE actually enjoyable..........this game.......this is just a choir to play and you get sick of Emo Paine, mental break down Yuna and MEGA cheer Rikki after about 2 hours.

It IS a brilliant game over all but the story does seem rather wacked out at times and X-2 really does show how bad square-enix becomes and the crap they end up giving us. I LOVED ffx when i first played it and would recommend X to any new people today and original gamers.

reviewText:
This is my story......

First played this on release on PS2, I was 22 at the time, it literally made me cry my eye's out at the end after spending 110+ hours on my first playthrough and being so invested in every character. For me, it's easily the best FF to date, with an awesome world, story and an absolute ton of secrets and side quests which are completely optional.

This port for me, is fantastic, after not being able to experience the previous 2 remasters (console only), it feels like SE have hit the nail on the head with this one, the upgraded visuals are fantastic and with extra effects such as AA and AO it looks great (for a 14 year old game) in full screen @ 1440p, always keeping a full 30fps (fortunately i have GSync, so with v-sync disabled the 30fps is unnoticable).
Obviously if you are coming to this game for the first time you can expect the story and some of the characters to be a bit cheesy and obvious, but it is final fantasy after all, and it is 14 year old.

Â£20 for a great port of not just FFX but also FFX-2 in my eyes is a steal, even if FFX-2 was really poor as a game compared to FFX.

reviewText:
Short and sweet.

You're not here to know if FFX is a good game. You know this already, this is why you are here. Unless maybe if you've been in a cave... on Mars... for the last 10 years.... with your eyes closed and your fingers in your ears. Then you haven't heard about the Final Fantasy franchise, and you stumbled here cause you throught the picture was pretty.

What you really want to know is if this is a good port. Square Enix has a bad reputation for making ports, and you want to know if this is an exception. You want to defeat SIN, but do not want to be defeated by the blue screen monster.

Rest assured, it is. This is a very decent port. Graphics are customisable (I play in 4k), game is stable with no CTD experienced so far, and it even has bonus options such as turbo mode and cheat mode. Furthermore I think the value is there with both games included in this bundle.

If you want to play FFX on PC, please proceed, you will not regret it.

reviewText:
- Running at 1920x1080 on High. Did fiddle around with the graphics settings, and to my surprise I haven't had a single frame drop. This game looks GORGEOUS. (For its age, of course)
- Game is running SMOOOOOOOTH. Any modern PC can run this game with no problems at all. Mine is very outdated.
- Original soundtrack! A big plus. The rearranged versions are hit or miss. I'll stick to the original.
- Japanese voices are there, but you might have to do some modding to get English subtitles with it.
- Xbox 360 controller works perfectly with no prior configuration needed. Buttons are remappable (if you like the US confirm/cancel schema, like me). Xbox button faces available ingame. From what I heard, Steam Controller won't work if you have another controller plugged in. Disconnect it and you should be good to go.
- Apparently this game uses XInput. No word on DInput. See above.
- 30 FPS lock. Sorry, 60 FPS enthusiasts. This doesn't bother me but some will hate it with a passion.
- Cutscenes cannot be skipped. This is a disappointment (exceptions are the prerendered CGIs)
- Haven't tested the boosters and I will not do so. I prefer the vanilla experience.


Played it until I reached Besaid, and I get the impression that this is indeed a great port and I am extremely satisfied. Final Fantasy X was the first RPG I ever finished and I played it to oblivion back in the day. This game brings back a lot of good memories of my teenage years.

It seems Square Enix did an excellent job on this one. Thank you very much for getting this port done right. My only complaint is the inability to skip cutscenes. Hoping for a mod later.

I don't often leave reviews, but I felt I had to for this.

A word of warning - FFX has been my favourite FF game since its original release on PS2. I know it has... flaws, but I still love it.

If you liked the original, get this. GET IT NOW.
