reviewText:
Final Fantasy X and X-2 are some of the most iconic games there are in existence, let alone the Final Fantasy series. This review will talk more about the differences between the Steam release and the original PS2 games, but in short, Final Fantasy X is a completely standalone game from the other games in the Final Fantasy series, and X-2 leads on from where X left off. Final Fantasy X sees you play as Tidus, a Blitzball payer from Zanarkand who gets flung into the world of Spira where he must assist Yuna on her pilgrimage to defeat Sin. X-2 switches control to Yuna, who has formed a group of Sphere Hunters with old friend Rikku and new friend Paine.

Port Quirks:
All in all, this is a pretty decent port. There's only 'partial' controller support, but the only important things that can't be controlled using a controller are the new boosters. Both keyboard and controller controls are bindable, which is very nice. There's multiple language selections, with both English and Japanese audio. The Japanese is a little buggy, though modders are already hard at work fixing that. For some reason, when I fired the game up for the first time, the game defaulted to Japanese text. This includes menu navigation, which can make it a little confusing to change back to English. Hopefully this is just a glitch, and not intended behaviour. Additionally, my game defaulted to a 1280x760 windowed resolution with 'low' graphic settings. This can easily be changed, but nonetheless is a slight gripe that others may encounter. Another nice feature of the port is achievements. The PS3 and PS4 versions had trophies, but the Steam version adds achievements for the truly hardcore players to try and complete. Can you get them all?

HD Remaster:
This Steam version is the equivalent of the PS3 & PS4's HD remaster, with a few differences. The HD remaster attempts to modernise the original PS2 game by improving the musical score and the graphics. Whether or not these are an improvement over the original music and graphics in the PS2 version is open to debate. Some of the new music sounds really great, but it naturally won't have the nostalgia of the original music -- there really is quite a difference. However, in this version all of the audio channels are on sliders. Want to increase the SFX while decreasing the background music? Now you can! The graphics are undoubtedly a vast improvement over the background objects from the original, with some smoother edges to the characters. Unfortunately, the character's eyes have been completely re-done, and in the process appear to have lost all emotion. Despite the facial 'improvements', they still haven't fixed the problem with the lip-syncing from the original Japanese audio to the English audio. The Steam version builds on the HD Remaster by allowing you to further customise the graphics, with adjustments to things such as screen resolution, brightness, shadow quality and anti-aliasing.

International Version:
There were a number of exclusives to the original PS2 game based on geographic region. The Steam version is based on the International Version, meaning you have access to them all! In Final Fantasy X, there's access to the new Expert Sphere Grid, for advanced players already familiar with the original game. There's also 10 new powerful optional bosses, plus one new powerful super-boss to track down and defeat. Included in the game selection menu is a video that fills in a bit of the story between the two games, along with some developer interviews as well. Finally, there are a few new skills for you to try out on the Sphere Grid. Final Fantasy X-2 boasts new Dresspheres, along with a new 'Creature Creator' and Field Arena tournaments. Now you can train monsters to fight alongside you! While it does make the game quite a bit easier, it is a nice new feature to play around with. There's also a brand new mission in Final Fantasy X-2 to try out, available from the game selection menu.

Steam Exclusive Features:
In addition to the features from the International Version, the Steam version adds a number of features that none of the previous versions have. These come in the form of 'boosters', that previous Steam Final Fantasy players may be familiar with. Essentially, they're little add-ons that make the game easier for you. In Final Fantasy X, you have a turbo mode that will increase the game by 2x or 4x speed, an option to always perform overdrives, an option to eliminate or change the rate of encounters, an option to have the characters battle automatically for you, and an option to disable the HUD. While the turbo feature can really come in handy on your 20th playthrough of the game, it sadly doesn't fast-forward through cut-scenes or FMVs, only actual gameplay. Some FMVs can be skipped, which is nice. The other features do feel a little like cheating, but some may find benefit in their use. If you really want to cheat, there's the option to max out your items, max out your Gil, and teach your characters all abilities.

Summary:
These two games are absolutely amazing, and this port does a decent job at bringing these classics to Steam. The price is cheap, and the games are well worth the money. For the games themselves, I'd give Final Fantasy X a 10/10, and Final Fantasy X-2 an 8/10. With regards to the Steam port, I'd give it a 7/10. If you haven't played either of the games before, I say that you simply must try them out. If you have played them before, you already know how amazing they are, so what are you waiting for? Go ahead and pick up this release right now! :)

reviewText:
Port review only.  10/10

I hate people that post reviews just to brag about their build but there's some things you need to know.

My experience with this port so far has been amazing but I'm able to crank it up to 4k and play it on high.  It looks great and plays smooth.  I'm running a i5-4760k and SLI GTX 970 FTWs on Windows 10.  I only overclock my CPU and RAM.  I've heard some complaints about multiple GPU performance but have not experienced any issues myself.  I'm running the most recent GeForce drivers.  I would recommend turning down your GPU to stock and make sure you have the latest drivers if you have any issues.  Some games don't do well overclocked because the GPU has to wait for other processes to be complete before turning the next frame.  That means, if you crank up your GPU...it just ends up waiting longer which can cause issues.  Some chipsets don't work well together either.  It's worth knowing you have a chipset specifically for your GPU.

I'm a fan of orchestrated music and this port allows you to use the arranged score in play of the original soundtrack.  They knocked it out of the park with this function.  The arranged score is beautiful and fits in perfect.

The gameplay is stable (on a stable system) and I've had no tearing, freezing, skipping, nor found any bugs to complain about up to Luca (haven't been xping much if at all).  I'll update once I'm through the story.

While the graphics settings only offer low, medium, and high...you can tweak settings through the Nvidia control panel if you are running on a lower resolution but want to smooth textures through antialiasing.  Good detail in shadows and lighting without messing with anything.  Increased environment detail.  Huge improvements on the original and leagues above the console HD versions if you have a powerful enough PC.

You can play on both the original and expert sphere grids.  Expert can be fun just to mix things up a bit if you've ran through the game at least once already.

I don't use the game boosters but you can speed up gameplay, turn off random encounters (might use that one later), get unlimited money, unlock all skills, and always full overdrive meter.

Great port for a great game.  Hope this helps.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy X/X2 HD comes finally makes it to PC. The good news is the wait has been worth it. It is a port of the HD remaster for PS3/PS4. Traditionally Square Enix Final Fantasy ports have been hit or miss for one reason or another. Some titles are ports of their mobile counterparts which doesn't translate well to PC.

I am glad to say that from the time I have spent with the game thus far the game has run at a steady frame rate on my i5 with a GTX 750 ti 2gb Vram OC'ed and 8 gb of total ram. I have not yet experienced a crash of any sort. Perhaps the game was easier to port from PS4 given the similar architecture. I am unsure if this is a port of the PS3 or PS4 version. What I will say is that the game looks great and comes with a variety of resolution options as well as windowed, full screen and borderless window.

In addition to those options the PC port also supports a variety of other video options including antialiasing, color correction, shadows, anisoptropic filtering, tex quality, post filter aa, unsharp mask, and Ambient occlusion.

These options are certainly welcome and a good step up from other ports from Square. Though it is disappointing the game still appears to be capped at 30fps. Its not a deal breaker as this isn't a fast paced shooter or anything where frame rate really matters.

The game also features a number of 'cheats' ranging from encounter rates to max items, gil and skill unlocks. These are nice options for people that may just want to experience the story. As you might expect acheivements are also available.

With the technical stuff out of the way, this is the same game you remember and love from the PS2 with a new coat of paint. If you never played the original or the remake. You play as Tidus a star Blitzball player and embark on an adventure to defeat Sin. On the way you will meet likeable characters and upgrade them using a sphere grid to unlock new abilities. There are plenty of side activities to partake in including Blitzball, finding all the aeons, acquiring Legendary weapons and more. X-2 is also included which is a matter of take it or leave it for some folks.

All in all FFX/X-2 HD for PC is a solid port and is something Square should carry forward from here on out and seek to raise the bar even higher.

*UPDATE*

I forgot to mention that the game features international content as well as rearranged music. Purists can still opt for the original soundtrack though. One of the only criticisms I really have is the same I had with the remaster on PS3/PS4. The updated main character models are quite nice. But the other NPC's don't really match the same attention to detail paid to the main characters. I realize though that overhauling the characters for all of the NPCs would have taken considerable time. But its a disappointment still.

reviewText:
I'll try to make this short and avoid using any childish puns.

FINAL FANTASY X

Final Fantasy X is a jRPG which tells the story of Tidus, a boy who enjoys Blitzball (basically Underwater Hand-ball) and has severe family issues. He's playing a blitzball game until he gets thrown several thousand years into the future by a giant whale thing. It's up to the player to help him figure out what's going on and how to go back home. The story isn't particularly original, but it can keep the player's interest until the end, and most characters are pretty cool

Combat is turn-based and lets you use all of your characters in battle, with only 3 appearing on screen at the same time that can be switched during each of your turns, leading to many tactical possibilities

The character growth system is very unique and involves a huge grid where your characters earn abilities and stat boosts by moving in it through the use of AP which can be acquired by killing enemies. Each character also has unique abilities called Overdrives, which can be obtained in many different ways, incentivating the player to explore the game in order to find new Overdrives and become stronger.

You can also take on several sidequests and minigames which can be fun timesinks (like Blitzball) or dreadful minigames designed by Satan himself (the lightning dodging and the butterfly catching)

FFX's graphics are nice, clean and smooth. The cutscenes still look enjoyable today (and some of them can be skipped now!) and watching Aeons wreck stuff is always amazing to look at.

reviewText:
Port review only.  10/10

I hate people that post reviews just to brag about their build but there's some things you need to know.

My experience with this port so far has been amazing but I'm able to crank it up to 4k and play it on high.  It looks great and plays smooth.  I'm running a i5-4760k and SLI GTX 970 FTWs on Windows 10.  I only overclock my CPU and RAM.  I've heard some complaints about multiple GPU performance but have not experienced any issues myself.  I'm running the most recent GeForce drivers.  I would recommend turning down your GPU to stock and make sure you have the latest drivers if you have any issues.  Some games don't do well overclocked because the GPU has to wait for other processes to be complete before turning the next frame.  That means, if you crank up your GPU...it just ends up waiting longer which can cause issues.  Some chipsets don't work well together either.  It's worth knowing you have a chipset specifically for your GPU.

I'm a fan of orchestrated music and this port allows you to use the arranged score in play of the original soundtrack.  They knocked it out of the park with this function.  The arranged score is beautiful and fits in perfect.

The gameplay is stable (on a stable system) and I've had no tearing, freezing, skipping, nor found any bugs to complain about up to Luca (haven't been xping much if at all).  I'll update once I'm through the story.

While the graphics settings only offer low, medium, and high...you can tweak settings through the Nvidia control panel if you are running on a lower resolution but want to smooth textures through antialiasing.  Good detail in shadows and lighting without messing with anything.  Increased environment detail.  Huge improvements on the original and leagues above the console HD versions if you have a powerful enough PC.

You can play on both the original and expert sphere grids.  Expert can be fun just to mix things up a bit if you've ran through the game at least once already.

I don't use the game boosters but you can speed up gameplay, turn off random encounters (might use that one later), get unlimited money, unlock all skills, and always full overdrive meter.

Great port for a great game.  Hope this helps.

reviewText:
Best Final Fantasy game ever.

Final Fantasy X is a mix between classic and modern Final Fantasy. The advanced turn-based battle system became the prototype for many JRPGs nowadays. It has the best story out of all FF games. The characters are very well written and everyone is important to the plot. There's no character that is useless in battles. You can also switch characters during battles.

The soundtracks are great and memorable.

For this PC port, SE actually did a good job for this, unlike their previous ports. It's based on the PS4 version, with even more features. It has graphic settings in the game (instead of just in the game launcher).

If you're a Final Fantasy fan and a JRPG fan, don't miss this one.

10/10 for the game.

9/10 for the port.

Masterpiece.

Better than Final Fantasy IX.

reviewText:
I'll review each game separately (Maybe some spoilers? Not really but you never know what people will consider to be spoilers).  I may be blinded by the nostalgia goggles a little bit, especially for X-2, but still a sincere review.

Final Fantasy X
Oh lord, where do I begin.  First played this game when I was 10 years old.  I'm turning 20 in two days and I'm still in love with this game.  In my original PS2 file, I have well over 300 hours in it, and since then with different save files and with the PS3 version and now the Steam version, I probably have nearly 1000 hours total (in FFX alone, not counting X-2).  Its captivating story is a good way to experience every emotion a good story will produce: anger, happiness, sadness, heartbreak, you name it.  It's a game from 2001 and made for controllers, so its graphics and keyboard layout are a little lackluster and frustrating, but graphics don't always make the game.  After you're finished with the story, there's always loads of extra stuff to do like stat maxing, celestial weapons, and Blitzball (however I seem to be the only person that thoroughly enjoys Blitzball).  With the Steam version, the addition of the Function key hacks make grinding far more bearable, even though there are some things that still need to be ironed out that probably won't (would be nice if in battles when you have the speed hack active it would disable dialogue so there wouldn't be long pauses between moves when someone talks, and sometimes it takes a while for whatever reason before a fiend casts magic.  Would also be nice if Blitzball would be affected by the increase in speed because those games can drag a bit if you have an enormous lead with an OP team).

tl;dr: Great game with an amazing story with lots to do. 10/10

Final Fantasy X-2
There's a lot of hate surrounding the game which I can understand I suppose, but it's pretty annoying to see all the time.  The game is focused around Yuna's story in a changed world from FFX.  Of course it'll be different.  FFX is an amazing game but the atmosphere after its ending would obviously be different.  There are several times in the game that makes me incredibly sad for her.  The percentage in relation to optional story missions makes exploring the game without a guide a LOT of fun (especially when I was a child and was still in awe by every video game I could find), and then playing with a guide is a lot of fun because there are several hidden things that would be near impossible to discover by yourself, not to mention the satisfaction of watching the percentage go up every few missions (be warned though: there are several guides that are wrong in their order/vague about what to do.  I haven't checked the guide on Steam so I can't say anything about that).  The Creature Creator is sort of tedious and obnoxious but is a great way to level grind/get more items that are exclusive to a single playthrough and whatnot.  The New Game+ option is great because then you can keep all of your stuff and ignore certain missions and choose a different side to experience another aspect of the game.  When I think of the FFX story, I pile the FFX-2 story with it because, in my opinion at least, the two complement each other nicely and make each other whole.

tl;dr: Ignore the hate for X-2, it's a good game if you don't try to play it in the same way as FFX. 9/10

reviewText:
Believe it or not, I'm a huge fan of The Spoony Experiment. And yes, I have seen his reviews of FFVIII all the way through XIII. And I like them! They're hilarious, and just about every problem he points out with these games has basis. Hell, most of the time, I think he's right. But you know what? I still have fun with Final Fantasy eight, ten, and even X-2. why? Well, it's kind of hard to describe.

I like Final Fantasy the same way I like the 4Kids dub of Yu-Gi-Oh. Yes, it's nostalgic and that's part of it, but more than the botched dub, more than the aggregious Americanizations, I can still see the heart underneath. The heart of the ones who made it with love and care.

As for FFX, it's kind of the same way. The dub is awful (sorry James Arnold Taylor, I loved you as Ratchet and you really didn't have much to work with here, but Tidus really does come across as whiney and shrill,) the plotline ludicrous at points, and there are far better games with deeper stories and just as much if not more fun to be had. Why do I still recommend this game? Because it's got the same sort of feeling as the first Kingdom Hearts, a real loving energy underneath everything that tells you the ones who made it really wanted to give life to this world. I also love post-apocalyptic fantasy settings and I hardly ever see them done at such length.

So be warned, FFX is an acquired taste, and some who drink will get violently ill and spit it out almost at once. But, if you can enjoy the campy goodness of a game of Shonen: Final Burst, still watch Sailor Moon or Inu Yasha, and remember fondly the days of the Playstation 2, then you'll have a great time with this game.

reviewText:
FFX in full HD glory on PC! Extensive graphics settings, play it in Japanese or English, choose between original and remastered soundtracks, international version content, game boosts, key bindings and options for maxed out resources and stats. And need I mention it's 2 games for the price of one! In the face of all this, the 30FPS lock isn't much of an issue. I must say, finally a really well done port. Good job SE!

FFX has a really beautiful story. One of the best JRPGs and one of the best in the series which is what people will tell you.
The last time I played FFX was more than 10 years ago, and I only finished 1/3 of the game. Now I can finish it in 1080p glory!

By all means, get this game.

P.S.: I never mentioned X-2 because I didn't really played it before. But what I can see is FFX garnered more attention and praise. Since you get both games, might as well play it.

reviewText:
Bought this game when it was released yesterday, and it ran atrociously. The game constantly crashed, and the glimpses I did get into game were at incredibly low fps, with many graphical glitches.

If this sounds like you, and you're using a laptop, the game might be using your integrated graphics card. Even though I had it set so that any application should automatically use my dedicated card, it was only ever using the integrated card for FFX, meaning it barely worked at all. There are plenty of guides online that can explain how to stop this better than I can, so go find them and you should be able to play!

About the actual games: FFX is fantastic. If you've never played a Final Fantasy game before, but are looking for somewhere to start, I would say this game is the best entry point to the series, as well as the entire genre of JRPGs. It has a great story, interesting gameplay and some of the best music of the series.

FFX-2 is...iffy. The story is pretty much a jumbled mess, unfortunately, but it has a few decent moments. Fortunately, it has interesting gameplay, and getting the chance to explore more of the world of Spira was enough to sell me on it.

reviewText:
Pros:

DS4 Controller Support: Originally I was nervous about buying this game because I use a DS4 controller which seems to have a mind of its own whether or not it will work with games. I'm super pleased that not only did my DS4 work perfectly, but I didn't have to even use a 3rd party tool like InputMapper or DS4Windows to get my controller recognized.

Cons:

x2/x4 Game Booster: needs to work with dialogue & cutscenes. Not just for speedrunners, but for people who just love the gameplay and want to skip through the dialogue that they've heard many many times already.

Auto-battle Game Booster: It makes sense that the developers wanted you to do certain battles on your own. The only thing that's annoying about the way they implemented it, is that it hard disables when you enter a mandatory battle; causing you to hit the button to re-enable it when the battle ends. Pretty annoying having to keep pressing the f3 key so often.

Bottom line: Without a doubt this is the best FFX-X2 yet.

reviewText:
Part 1 - FFX
By far the best game I played. Played it on PS2, fell in love with the game. Played it on PS3, fell in love again. Played it on PC, still amazed after all these years.
- Good Graphics (I do like the HD upgrade, cut scenes still amazing)
- Create music (The re-arranging of sounds are really good, though the original scores are nostalgic which I love the most)
- Amazing storyline. After all these years, still amazed at the end.

Part 2 - FFX-2
It's a change. Though I do like this refreshing change. Same with Part 1, played it all the versions there are.
- Good Graphics,  great cutscene graphics.
- Really love the soundtracks.
- Good story, I really like the plot twists but it fell a bit short at the end with the option of multiple endings.

Part 2.5 - FFX-2 Last mission
- Did not really like this minigame version. Expects more then just a board-game like gamestyle


After all these hours, a few tears I feel there is still room for a part 3, FFX-3.
In every version, (spoiler) Tidus returns at the end somehow, but what happened to him? How is Spira doing? Why did Yuna change so much and FFX-Will opens up a whole new story where Tidus is back.

I really do hope Square Enix will make FFX-3.

reviewText:
(Edit/TLDR : FFX is a fun classic. FFX-2 is a steaming pile of garbage-flavoured garbage smothered in gatbage sauce with a nice bowl of garbage on the side)

(Review based on FFX only, playing the games in order)

The camera is awkward in spots, hurray for unskippable cutscenes, and oh dear God that voice acting.

The redone graphics are mostly quite nice and the main characters look great, but you can see they didn't put nearly the effort into background/secondary characters(understandable, if slightly disappointing.) Not having played it since it's original PS2 release, I've forgot enough of the story that it feels fresh and engaging, even if I remember most of the big spoilers. I had honestly forgotten how much I enjoy this game, and am very happy to have it available once again.

Is it a perfect game? Nope, not even when it was first released, but it is a fun, engaging game with some minor flaws, and annoying new gameplay issues (see dark anima, 'optional' bosses my a$$) that can be overlooked and is still reasonable value for money.

(Review based on FFX-2)
*vomits*

Recommended with a  7/10 for FFX, and a (kill it with fire)/10 for FFX-2

reviewText:
HOW MANY YEARS HAVE I WAITED FOR THIS DAY!!!!

No I am really serious, I verged off of the playstation line years ago and soo dissapointed that my childhood game never was ported outside the playstation series.

Soo onto my review,

The game started up just fine in all resolutions that I tested it on. A glitch happened where I changed resolutions in the game menu and windows was having a hissy fit and would not stop switching between resolutions.

Also the 30 fps framelock is honestly quite annoying I can run this game higher than 30 fps but for some reason the ingame menu has no problem running 61 fps...

The game was played on an Xbox 360 controller and all buttons were responsive except when I tried Aurons bushido I could not execute it properly. In my honest opinion the developers should include full controller support for a wider variety of controllers. This is Final Fantasy 10 after all.. one of the best selling final fantasies out there.

This game brings back alot of memories of good times in my life. After over 200+ hours alone of playing this game on the ps2 I was more than excited for this port and I was not disapointed. It was not day zero broken, or changed in many ways. I still had the final fantasy 10 feel to it as the same when I was a child. The game runs smoothly even after being at only 30 fps ( It doesnt bother me too much I just wish it could be higher)

In summary of my awesome review, This is not a bad PC port. I dont have a quirk for dual audio soo I decided to leave it off this review. I am for right now"glad that this game was even ported to the PC soo I can once again play it."

reviewText:
[Edit] So I spent a lot of time on my original review but I am deleting and rewriting it!

My original review was stressing how unoptimised this game is and how much better the console experience is. Originally I dealt with multiple issues on simply getting the game to work on my high end pc rig. The game now runs fine and in full screen. To prevent the game being choppy and ultimately crashing I have moved my graphics down to low. This is what really made the game playable for me however I still feel a little begrudged playing a HD remake game on low graphics while I could be comfortably sat on my couch with the way more optimised PSVita version.

The game does now run a lot better and if you are a pc only kind of guy who does not have access to a console version of the game then I would more than recommend this version as it is still better than a life without FFX. However if you do have a PSVita (I believe there are PS3 and PS4 versions also), then I would highly recommend playing it on them instead. If i'm honest I didn't expect this version to be the definetive version and the majority of ports seem to be more lackluster than their console counterparts.

Gameplay wise this game is fantastic. I personally still own the PS2 versions of these games and also the original HD version on the PSVita and have still come back for more on steam. The characters are brilliant and the story is everything you expect from the Final Fantasy franchise (unless you jumped in on the XIII saga of games). Personally one of my favourite FF games after Crisis Core, 7 and 6 oooh and 9. Definitely a bargain for the amount of content within these games. Â£20 pounds will buy you hundreds of hours of content and if you can pick it up on a sale you are laughing.

I hope to see more remakes and re-releases of classic JRPGs like this one on steam soon!

reviewText:
Final Fantasy X (not X-2)

It's been many years since I played this, my absolute favorite Final Fantasy game to date (FFX) and the goosebumps on my arm speak for themselves, and they keep coming back.

PROS:
* This is hands down one of the best games i've ever played.
* Competitor of Final Fantasy VII.
* Combat System.
* Time Warp (x2 and x4).
* Autosaves.
* Story.
* Soundtrack (Nobuo Uematsu).

CONS:
* The dialogue is rediculous and annoying at times.
* Very long and unskippable cutscenes.
* Lots of upscaled textures.
* 30 FPS.

I am not a fan of anime or JRPGs but I find this game surprisingly tolerable, not counting FFX-2 which spins out of control.

reviewText: I'm very disappointed I can't get past the opening cut scene leading to the title screen. I've read that a lot of people are having issues with their video syncing with the audio or the game crashing quite often. I'm hoping for a patch in the near future. I'm using a brand new gaming laptop with nice specs (haven't had any issue with any other games). I'd like to play one of my favorite Final Fantasy games in the series, but this crashing 20 seconds in is frustrating.\n\nI highly recommend this game on PS2! Laptop, I'll get back to you once I can play the game properly.
